texts.shortText: Fairly-large wader with distinctively long, downwardly-curved, dark brown beak, often with fleshy base. Top of head brown with pale median line, another pale stripe above eye and a dark stripe though dark-brown eye. Rest of upper body speckled densely in brown; lower back, belly and rump white.  Legs and feet grey.
Total length 40-46 cm, wingspan 76-88 cm, mass c 400 g, sexes alike, but female larger than male and with longer bill.

Global: Breeds in northern hemisphere in both Asia and N Europe. Summer migrant to coastal areas of Africa, Asia and Australia.

Local/Regional: Along coast across whole region.

Found mostly along the coast or in coastal wetlands and estuaries and not on inland water bodies. Roosts in flocks at high tide, often communally with other shorebirds. Flight rapid and low over water. Forages single or in loose groups both by day and at night, mostly in intertidal zone, following the tide as it falls. Usually walks continuously while foraging, but may pause with one foot raised before darting forward to capture burrowing crabs.
Takes mostly crabs and mudprawns, but also molluscs, polychaete worms and small fish.
Does not breed in South Africa, but in northern latitudes, where 3-4 eggs laid in a bare scrap on the ground in tundra of arctic moorland.

Long, downwardly-curved beak distinguishes Whimbrel from most other waders, but similar to Eurasian curlew. That species is 30% larger with longer beak and legs and no stripes on head and is mostly in wetlands and lagoons (especially Langebaan Lagoon) and seldom on exposed seashores.

Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa (Fourth edition). Struik Nature, Cape Town. (p. 346).

Hockey, PAR, Dean, WRJ & Ryan, PG (2005). Robertâ€™s Birds of Southern Africa (7th edition). The Trustees of the John Voelckler Book Fund, Cape Town. (p. 349).
